results.title: Jonathan Miller's London
results.creator_credit: John McGreevy, Pat Ferns and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cities”.
Dr Jonathan Miller gives his personal view of the historical development of the city of London including his own personal upbringing in that city.

results.title: Jonathan Livingston seagull
results.creator_credit: Hall Bartlett, JLS Partnership and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Richard Bach’s best selling novel about spiritual development and human achievement is brought to life in this rendition, complete with a Neil Diamond soundtrack. The story begins with a flock of seagulls pecking at garbage left by a boat. One of these seagulls - Jonathan (voice supplied by James Franciscus), longs to soar above his current existence, reaching dizzying heights and be the fastest seagull. Thus he leaves the flock to see the world and in search of speed. On reaching aviary heaven he meets Maureen Seagull (voice supplied by Juliet Mills) who introduces Jonathan to new experiences. Jonathan returns to his flock with new found knowledge but the other seagulls are sceptical until he performs a miracle and Jonathan is elevated to a messianic hero. Voices also supplied by Philip Ahn, Richard Crenna, Kelly Harmon and Hal Holbrook.

results.title: Jonas Salk: science of life
results.creator_credit: Peter Poor, Isaac Kleinerman and CBS Network
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Dr Jonas Salk, at his Institute for Biological Studies, is seeking ways to fuse the two disciplines of the scientist and humanist. It is vital for scientists and humanists to work together, he claims, ‘to make the decisions and choices that nature has made until now…for the greatest value to human life and society as a whole’.

results.title: Jonas Mekas: Three friends
results.brief_description: Born in Lithuania in 1922, Jonas Mekas was displaced from his homeland by the Soviet and Nazi invasions of World War II. Arriving in New York in 1949 with his brother, the two took to New York and having bought a camera, started to document their new lives and all that unfurled around them. This work, “Three friends” is divided into two parts, “Zefrido Tonro” and “Happy birthday to John”. “Zefiro Tonrna” includes images of close friend George Maciunas from 1952, then proceeds to the 1970s, displaying Fluxus (an avant-garde art movement) events and performances and picnics with friends, including Yoko Ono, John Lennon and Andy Warhol. Narrated by Mekas (reading from his diary), who laments the physical demise of Maciunas whilst displaying the spiritedness of Mekas’ involvement in New York’s art scene. “Happy birthday to John” On October 9th 1972, half of the music world gathered in Syracuse New York to celebrate the opening of John Lennon/Yoko Ono Fluxus show, designed by George Maciunas. The same day a smaller group gathered in a local hotel room to celebrate John’s birthday. Part two of “Three friends” is a record of this occasion, documenting the camaraderie of Lennon and Ono’s group of friends and associates. Soundtrack consists of singing by John, Yoko, Ringo Starr, Allen Ginsberg and Phil Oaks, among others. Also includes footage of a Lennon/Ono concert at Madison Square Garden (August 30, 1972) and the vigil in Central Park, December 8, 1980, as well as other rare footage.

results.title: Jonas Mekas: lost lost lost
results.brief_description: Born in Lithuania in 1922, Jonas Mekas was displaced from his homeland by the Soviet and Nazi invasions; “Lost, lost, lost” comprises fourteen years of filming starting from his arrival in America as a political refugee. Filmed over the years 1949-1963 and edited in 1976, the film documents the New York counterculture of the ‘50s and the development of Mekas’ own filming style. In Mekas’ own words “the period I am dealing with in these six reels was a period of desperation, of attempts to desperately grow roots into the new ground, create new memories”. “Lost lost lost” then is a beautifully elegiac poem, a paean to the nature of memory and meaning of experiences wrought in a new land whilst participating in an exciting new sub-culture, burgeoning with possibility for change. Divided into six reels Mekas narrates and places intertitles between sections of film that give context to his images. His empathy for post-war immigrants is transparent; his fascination for the street life of Brooklyn, and in particular the poor suburb of Williamsburg where he lived; Mekas also conveys his melancholy for all that has passed. Reel one deals with Mekas’ displacement and discovery of the city, his enduring loneliness and links with the Lithuanian community; Reel two depicts various social events including a wedding and New Year’s Eve celebration; Reel 3 displays the hold that cinema increasingly has on the Mekas’ brothers; Reel 4 reveals the brothers’ fascination for activism, depicting marches and protests; in Reel 5 Mekas reveals a newfound peace as he reconnects with rural life; Reel 6 marks Mekas’ continuing journey as a filmmaker as he begins to fraternise with poets and artists from the Beat Generation. A diaristic filmmaker and poet, Mekas portrays this period in American history as tumultuous, and his essayist account gives insight into the emotions behind the experiences of displaced persons, personalising the post-War period of American prosperity and social change.

results.title: Jollies
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: An intimate and sardonic work about being an adolescent in mid-American suburbia. From touching the genitals of boys in school to finally getting to kiss the girl she wants, this very funny and accomplished experimental work was filmed while the director was herself a teen.

results.title: Joker
results.creator_credit: Brian Adler, Todd Phillips, Bradley Cooper, Emma Tillinger Koskoff, Mark Friedberg, Mark Bridges, Scott Silver, DC Comics, DC Films, DC Entertainment, Creative Wealth Media Finance, Bron Studios, Village Roadshow Pictures, Joint Effort and Warner Bros. Pictures
results.headline_credit: Canada and United States of America, 2019
results.brief_description: During the 1980s, a failed stand-up comedian is driven insane and turns to a life of crime and chaos in Gotham City while becoming an infamous psychopathic crime figure.

constellations_other.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_other.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.title: Jojo Rabbit
results.headline_credit: Czech Republic, New Zealand and United States of America, 2019
results.brief_description: A World War II satire that follows a lonely German boy whose world view is turned upside down when he discovers his single mother is hiding a young Jewish girl in their attic. Aided only by his idiotic imaginary friend, Adolf Hitler, Jojo must confront his blind nationalism.

results.title: Jojo's blues
results.creator_credit: Peter Wallach, Jane Warrenbrand and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Tells the story of Teddy’s dangerous initiation into a gang led by Jojo and Scat. When Jojo has a close escape he tries to bribe Teddy into keeping the fiasco a secret, but Teddy refuses not only the money, but also membership in the club. “I’d like to be friends with you guys,” he says, “but the price is just not right.” Animated.
